questions.text: A 40-year-old man attends a physical rehabilitation session. One month ago, the patient had a motor vehicle accident that resulted in a posterior hip dislocation. The injury caused damage to the nerve that innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. Which of the following movements is most likely affected by this injury?
questions.solution:
The hip joint is a ball and socket joint formed by the articulation of the head of the femur with the acetabulum of the pelvis. Movements of the hip joint include flexion and extension, internal rotation and external rotation, and adduction and abduction. These movements are controlled by different groups of muscles in the hip:   
  •  Adduction: performed by actions of the adductor magnus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, gracilis, and pectineus 
  •  Abduction: performed by actions of the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata, and sartorius 
  •  Extension: performed by actions of the gluteus maximus and hamstrings 
  •  Flexion: performed by actions of the iliopsoas, pectineus, rectus femoris, and sartorius  
  •  Internal rotation is performed by the tensor fascia lata, gluteus medius, and gluteus minimus 
  •  External rotation: performed by actions of the obturator muscle, gluteus maximus, and piriformis  

Option Analysis

✅ Extension of the thigh  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abduction of the thigh :
Incorrect: Abduction of the thigh at the hip joint is facilitated by the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, tensor fascia lata, and sartorius muscles, but not the gluteus maximus.  
❌ Adduction of the thigh  :
Incorrect: Hip adductors include the adductor magnus, longus, brevis, gracilis, and pectineus. The gluteus maximus muscle is not involved in hip or thigh adduction. 
❌ Internal rotation of the thigh :
Incorrect: The gluteus maximus is involved in external rotation of the thigh, not internal rotation.  
❌ Flexion of the thigh :
Incorrect: The gluteus maximus extends, as opposed to flexes, the thigh at the hip joint.

questions.text: A three-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to gait disturbance. The patient’s parents have noticed that their son has been falling more frequently while running. In addition, they have observed that he appears to have “knock knees.” They deny any significant injury, and the boy has not been complaining of pain. He was born full-term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and is up to date on vaccinations. He can name familiar objects, climbs well, and follows instructions. On physical examination he is well-developed, well-nourished, and speaks in 3-4 word sentences. Physical examination is notable for bilateral genu valgum. His knees are nontender and he has full range of motion without pain. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral genu valgum on physical examination. Clinically and radiographically, valgus deformity will present as “knock knees,” whereas varus deformity will present as “bow legs”. Genu valgum can be a normal finding in patients between the ages of 2-5 years. In the majority of toddlers with physiologic genu valgum, the condition will resolve with age as the long bones of the legs continue to ossify. While genu valgum may be a standard variant in toddlers, it can also represent a pathologic disturbance in the development of long bones.

Measurement of the Q-angle can be used to assess the alignment of the knee joint This angle is found by measuring the angle formed between the quadriceps muscles and the patella tendon. The normal Q angle falls between 12 and 20 degrees when the knee is extended, with males normally falling at the low end of this range and females in the high end.

Large Q-angles outside of the normal range are associated with varus deformities that can be caused by underlying nutritional deficiencies, skeletal dysplasias, growth disorders, or persistence of severe physiologic genu varus after the age of 2 years. Small Q-angles outside of the normal range are indicative of valgus deformity, which may be physiologic in toddlers, or the result of rickets or an underlying skeletal dysplasia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Physiologic genu valgum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cozen fracture:
Incorrect: Cozen fractures are fractures of the proximal tibial metaphysis that can occur in children. They  typically present after an injury with pain of the affected knee. Patients with proximal tibial metaphysis fractures are at risk for developing valgus deformity secondary to medial physeal overgrowth during the healing response. In contrast, this patient has not suffered an injury, is not in any pain, and has bilateral valgus deformity.  
❌ Vitamin D deficiency:
Incorrect: Rickets from Vitamin D deficiency is a common cause of valgus deformity in countries without access to advanced medical care. The bone deformities associated with Rickets typically appear before the age of 18 months. The condition is unlikely in this child given his age and history of adequate nutritional intake.  
❌ Chondroectodermal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Chondroectodermal dysplasia (Ellis van Creveld syndrome) is an autosomal recessive skeletal dysplasia that results in short-limbed disproportionate dwarfism. This disorder is also known to be associated with cardiac anomalies. Patients can have genu valgum, but this patient does not have other features consistent with disproportionate dwarfism.  
❌ Skeletal dysplasia:
Incorrect: Skeletal dysplasia refers to a category of rare genetic disorders that affect the development of bones and joints and can lead to genu valgum. The condition causes abnormally shaped bones, especially in the head, spine, arms, and legs. This patient is without other associated skeletal anomalies on physical examination.

questions.text: A study was made on the dynamics of skeletal muscle fibers during muscle contractions. A sarcomere unit was examined under the microscope to investigate changes in muscle sarcomere parts during contraction. Two bands shorten in length, but one band remains the same. Which is this band?
questions.solution:
The muscle fibers are made of myofibrils. Myofibrils are made of myofilaments. These myofilaments contain actin and myosin overlapping and make up the muscle's basic contractile unit called a sarcomere.    

Sarcomeres are the building blocks of the skeletal muscles made of arrays of thin actin filaments and thick myosin filaments aligned perpendicularly. When the sarcomere is examined under electron microscopy, the parts of the sarcomere can be identified. First, the A band is the area in the middle of the sarcomere where actin and myosin overlap. In the middle of the A band, the H band (which is paler in color) and M line can also be seen. The H band is the area in the middle of the A band that contains no actin filaments. Finally, the A band is surrounded by two pale regions. These are the  I bands, which have only actin filaments without overlapping myosin. These I bands include the Z lines in the middle, and the sarcomere unit extends from one Z line to the other.    

During muscle contraction, the muscle fibers shorten as the myosin pulls on the overlapping actin filaments. This results in a shortening of the I band and H band. However, the A band always remains the same in contraction and relaxation.  


Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: These are the Z lines inside the I band. The Z lines are pulled closer together when the muscles contract because the I band shortens.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: This is the M line that is inside the H band.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This is the I band. The I band shortens during muscle contraction.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This is the H band which also shortens during muscle contraction.  
✅ E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to a clinic for a wellness examination. During the visit, bilateral patellar reflexes are evaluated by tapping the patellar tendons with a reflex hammer. Which of the following best characterizes the neural pathway responsible for regulating the flexor muscles involved in this reflex?

choices.text: Type Ia sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron
Type II sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron

questions.solution:
The patellar reflex is an example of a myotatic stretch reflex. The reflex is elicited by tapping against the patellar tendon, which leads to stretching of muscle spindles within the extensor muscles of the thigh (quadriceps). To prevent overstretching, the flexor muscles of the thigh (hamstrings) are inhibited, whereas the extensor muscles (quadriceps) are activated.  

Inhibition of the flexor muscles is mediated via a three-neuron pathway. Signals from the peripheral are transmitted to the spinal cord via type II sensory neurons. The type II sensory neurons then synapse in the anterior horn with interneurons, which send inhibitory signals to the flexor muscles via α-motor neurons.   

In contrast, activation of the extensor muscles is mediated via a two-neurons pathway. Signals from the periphery are transmitted via type Ia sensory neurons. These neurons then stimulate α-motor neurons.  

The end result of extensor muscle contraction and flexor muscle relaxation is knee extension, which helps decrease stretching of the patellar tendon and quadriceps muscle.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Type Ia sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The patellar reflex is caused by stretching of the patellar tendon. Type Ia sensory neurons transmit signals from the stretch receptors to the spinal cord. These neurons then synapse with α-motor neurons to trigger activation of the extensor muscles within the thigh, thereby preventing overstretching.  
❌ Type Ia sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the neuronal pathway responsible for regulating the extensor muscles involved in the patellar reflex.  
❌ Type 1b sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The patellar reflex is an example of a stretch reflex. Afferent signals are transmitted via type Ia and II neurons, but not via type Ib neurons.  
❌ Type II sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: Type II sensory neurons synapse with an interneuron, which then synapses with an α-motor neuron, to regulate the flexor muscles in the patellar reflex.  
✅ Type II sensory neuron → Interneuron → α-motor neuron   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is working in a warehouse and lifts a heavy carton of apples. There is shortening of the biceps brachii, which activates the golgi tendon organs within the muscle. Which of the following best describes the neuronal pathway via which signals from the golgi tendon organs help prevent biceps over-contraction?

choices.text: Type Ib sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron
Type II sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron
Type Ia sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron

questions.solution:
The golgi tendon reflex prevents damage to muscles secondary to over-contraction.  

The reflex is facilitated by golgi tendon organs, which are proprioceptors found in the tendons. When the golgi tendon organs of a muscle are compressed, they fire more action potentials. These action potentials travel through type Ib afferent fibers to the spinal cord.    

Within the posterior horn of the spinal cord, they synapse with inhibitory interneurons, which in turn, synapse with α-motor neurons of the contracting muscle.    

At the same time, type Ib afferent neurons also synapse with stimulatory interneurons that synapse with α-motor neurons innervating the antagonist muscles.    

The net result is relaxation of the flexed muscle and contraction of the antagonist muscles, thereby preventing the flexed muscles from being damaged through over-contraction  

Option Analysis

✅ Type Ib sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type Ib sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons to the spinal cord. In the spinal cord, the sensory neurons synapse with an inhibitory interneuron, which then relays signals back to the muscles via α-motor neurons.  
❌ Type II sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons, not type II sensory neurons.  
❌ Type II sensory neuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons, not type II sensory neurons. Moreover, this reflex arc involves an inhibitory interneuron.  
❌ Type Ia sensory neuron → Inhibitory interneuron → α-motor neuron  :
Incorrect: The golgi tendon reflex prevents muscle over-contraction and damage. In this reflex arc, signals from the golgi tendon organs are transmitted via type Ib sensory neurons, not type Ia sensory neurons.

questions.text: A study is conducted on a peripheral neuromuscular disease. In the study, the disease was found to occur secondary to autoimmune destruction of neuromuscular junction motor end-plate receptors. Which of the following is true regarding the type of these receptors and their associated signaling molecule?
questions.solution:
Contractions of skeletal muscle fibers are controlled by the motor nerves, and the lower motor nerves supply muscle fibers at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ). Three structures are found in the NMJ: the axon nerve terminals of the lower motor neurons, the synaptic cleft, and the postsynaptic membrane of the skeletal muscle fiber (i.e. the motor end plate).

When action potentials reach the axon terminal, depolarization results in the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft, which then acts on the nicotinic receptors in the motor end plate, resulting in the propagation of action potentials to the muscle fibers, resulting in muscle contraction.  
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The motor end plate receptors are nicotinic receptors, not cholinergic receptors.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Acetylcholine is the signaling molecule for the nicotinic receptor in the motor end plate, not epinephrine.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The motor end plate receptors are nicotinic receptors, and the signaling molecule for these receptors is acetylcholine.   
❌ :
Incorrect: The receptors in the motor end plate are nicotinic receptors.

questions.text: A study is underway to understand the effects of parathyroid hormone on controlling bone formation and resorption. Scientists agree that the hormone contributes to bone remodeling and is affected by serum calcium levels. Calcium ions act on the calcium-sensing receptors on the parathyroid glands and subsequent serum levels of parathyroid hormone. Which of the following is true regarding parathyroid hormone?

choices.text: Chronic serum elevation in parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone
Low intermittent elevation of serum parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone
Parathyroid hormone directly stimulates osteoclasts to increase bone resorption
Parathyroid hormone stimulates apoptosis of osteoclasts while inhibiting the apoptosis of osteoblasts.
Serum elevations in parathyroid hormone increase bone resorption, regardless of the duration of elevation.

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is a significant hormone in controlling calcium homeostasis and bone resorption and formation. PTH stimulates osteoblasts to increase the production of RANK ligand (RANKL), which then activates osteoclasts and thus bone resorption. In addition, PTH enhances bone formation by increasing osteoblast proliferation and differentiation and decreasing osteoblast apoptosis. Therefore, the effects of parathyroid hormone on the bones can be anabolic or catabolic, depending on the periodicity and duration of PTH secretion.  

When there are continuous PTH serum elevations, there will be primarily catabolic effects on the bones. On the other hand, low intermittent exposure to PTH leads to anabolic effects on the bone, increasing bone formation. Due to this effect, low intermittent administration of PTH is often used in the management of osteoporosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic serum elevation in parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low intermittent elevation of serum parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone  :
Incorrect: Low intermittent secretion of parathyroid hormone has been shown to have anabolic effects on the bone. It stimulates bone formation without resorption.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone directly stimulates osteoclasts to increase bone resorption  :
Incorrect: Parathyroid hormone stimulates osteoclasts indirectly by stimulating the osteoblasts to increase the secretion of RANK ligand, which then activates osteoclasts.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone stimulates apoptosis of osteoclasts while inhibiting the apoptosis of osteoblasts.  :
Incorrect: This stem describes the effects of estrogen, not a parathyroid hormone.  
❌ Serum elevations in parathyroid hormone increase bone resorption, regardless of the duration of elevation.   :
Incorrect: Low intermittent secretion of parathyroid hormone has been shown to have anabolic effects on bone, while the chronic elevation of parathyroid hormone has catabolic effects on bone.

questions.text: A group of scientists is evaluating the effects of estrogen on bone remodeling in an attempt to find new treatments for osteoporosis. In their study, estrogen deficiency is associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis. Which of the following is true regarding the effects of estrogen on  bone remodeling?

choices.text: Estrogen inhibits bone resorption via both direct and indirect effects on osteoclasts
The effects of estrogen on bones occur primarily in women, while testosterone has more prominent effects in men
Estrogen inhibits bone resorption but does not affect bone formation
Estrogen induces apoptosis in both osteoblasts and osteoclasts
Estrogen's effects on osteoclasts occur indirectly through osteoblasts.

questions.solution:
Estrogen is a hormone that plays a significant role in bone homeostasis in men and women and affects bone formation and resorption. Estrogen inhibits bone remodeling and resorption due to its direct and indirect effect on osteoclasts. Directly, estrogen binds to its receptor sites on osteoclasts and induces apoptosis. Estrogen also inhibits osteoclasts indirectly by decreasing the production and responsiveness to RANK-ligand.  

Additionally, estrogen stimulates bone formation by inhibiting apoptosis of osteocytes and osteoblasts. Estrogen also increases osteoblasts' production and lifespan, thus increasing bone formation. However, estrogen induces the closure of the epiphyseal growth plate, thereby limiting the linear growth of bones.  

Option Analysis

✅ Estrogen inhibits bone resorption via both direct and indirect effects on osteoclasts  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The effects of estrogen on bones occur primarily in women, while testosterone has more prominent effects in men  :
Incorrect: In both women and men, estrogen is a significant contributor to bone remodeling  
❌ Estrogen inhibits bone resorption but does not affect bone formation  :
Incorrect: Estrogen both inhibits bone resorption and stimulates bone formation.  
❌ Estrogen induces apoptosis in both osteoblasts and osteoclasts  :
Incorrect: Estrogen inhibits apoptosis of osteoblasts and promotes apoptosis in osteoclasts.  
❌ Estrogen's effects on osteoclasts occur indirectly through osteoblasts.  :
Incorrect: Estrogen receptors are present on osteoclasts, and its effects on these cells are both direct and indirect.
